rows.name: title_0
rows.value: Conflict forecast

rows.name: text_0_1
rows.value: This README provides some technical details on the provided datasets, forecast methods and model performance we provide on [Conflict Forecast app](http://conflict-forecast.web.app/). For any specific requests or queries please do not hesitate to reach out to us at conflictforecast@gmail.com.

rows.name: title_1
rows.value: Method details

rows.name: text_1_1
rows.value: We predict intensification of existing conflicts and locations where new conflicts will break out after a period of peace. We provide sub-national forecasts of conflict intensity at the admin2 level with different forecast horizons. Currently, the forecasts displayed in the [Conflict Forecast app](conflict-forecast.web.app) are for three months ahead.

rows.name: text_1_2
rows.value: When the forecast window is three months, we predict, for example, the likelihood of any riot occurring within that entire period. The same applies to the intensity forecast â€” for a three-month forecasting window, we estimate the sum of fatalities over the next three months.

rows.name: text_1_3
rows.value: Although we are continuously experimenting with different models and ensembles, we typically rely on a Random Forest and implement a rolling forecast methodology. The purpose of the rolling forecast is to replicate the information set that would be available to a decision maker.

rows.name: text_1_4
rows.value: We train models to learn a functional form using global data from 2012 onward. With the resulting model, we generate out-of-sample predictions on a rolling basis from 2020 onward.

rows.name: text_1_5
rows.value: For any violence/conflict, hyperparameters are chosen by maximising the area under the curve (AUC) of the receiver operating characteristics (ROCs) curve. In the case of violence intensity, we seek to minimise the mean squared error (MSE). These metrics are calculated for the entire dataset and specifically for challenging cases (onsets). We define challenging cases as admin2_unit-months where there has been no riots/fatalities in the last 24 months.

rows.name: title_2
rows.value: Target variables and feature sets

rows.name: subtitle_2_1
rows.value: Target variables:

rows.name: text_2_1
rows.value:
* Any conflict (riot): The target variable is a binary indicator of at least one conflict (riot) in the location.
* Violence intensity: The target variable is the number of fatalities. More specifically, we predict the log of fatalities plus one.

In both cases we rely on [Armed Conflict Location & Event Data (ACLED)](https://acleddata.com/) data.

rows.name: subtitle_2_2
rows.value: Feature sets:

rows.name: text_2_2
rows.value:
Text features: 15 topics generated by an latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA) model that analyzes over 6 million news articles.

* Historical violence: information about past violence of the admin2 unit and neighboring units, extracted from [Armed Conflict Location & Event Data (ACLED)](https://acleddata.com/) and [Uppsala Conflict Data Program (UCDP)](https://ucdp.uu.se/).
* Other features include population-related variables from [GlobPop](https://github.com/lulingliu/GlobPOP), geostatistics from [Earth Data](https://www.earthdata.nasa.gov/), and election data, compiled by the Conflict Forecast team.

rows.name: text_2_3
rows.value: Note that we include features attributed to both the admin unit and neighboring units. We consider an admin unit a neighbor if its midpoint falls within a specific distance range from the border. The defined ranges are ['0-5', '5-25', '25-100', '100-500'] km.

rows.name: title_3
rows.value: Contextualization of the predictions

rows.name: text_3_1
rows.value: After obtaining predictions, we overlay them with other data layers to provide early warnings of potential disruptions to infrastructure due to riots or other events that may lead to fatalities.

rows.name: text_3_2
title_4
rows.value: Disclaimer:

rows.name: text_4_1
rows.value: The predicted numbers are estimates and should be used as a supplementary data source for decision-making. They do not replace expert analysis and should be interpreted with caution.

rows.name: title_5
rows.value: Citation:

rows.name: text_5_1
rows.value: Please cite our work as:
